coredata.dc:description: Solid polymer electrolytes (SPEs) have been considered the most promising separators for all-solid-state lithium metal batteries (ASSLMBs) due to their ease of processing and low cost. However, the practical applications of SPEs in ASSLMBs are limited by their low ionic conductivities and mechanical strength. Herein, we developed a three-dimensional (3D) interconnected MXene (Ti3C2Tx) network and Li6.4La3Zr1.4Ta0.6O12 (LLZTO) particles synergistically reinforced polyethylene oxide (PEO)-based SPE, where the association of Li+ with ether-oxygen in PEO could be significantly weakened through the Lewis acid-base interactions between the electron-absorbing group (Ti–F, −O–) of Ti3C2Tx and Li+. Besides, the TFSI− in lithium salts could be immobilized by hydrogen bonds from the Ti–OH of Ti3C2Tx. The 3D interconnected Ti3C2Tx network not only alleviated the agglomeration of inorganic fillers (LLZTO), but also improved the mechanical strength of composite solid electrolyte (CSE). Consequently, the assembled Li||CSE||Li symmetric battery showed excellent cycling stability at 35 ℃ (stable cycling over 3000 h at 0.1 mA cm−2, 0.1 mAh cm−2) and −2 ℃ (stable cycling over 2500 h at 0.05 mA cm−2, 0.05 mAh cm−2). Impressively, the LiFePO4||CSE||Li battery showed a high discharge capacity of 145.3 mAh/g at 0.3 C after 300 cycles at 35 ℃. This rational structural design provided a new strategy for the preparation of high-performance solid-state electrolytes for lithium metal batteries.

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: A new high performance PEO-based solid electrolyte was prepared by the synergistic effect of Ti3C2Tx MXene/PAN nanofiber and LLZTO, which exhibits high ionic conductivity, excellent mechanical properties and outstanding electrochemical stability due to the uniform dispersion of LLZTO in the electrolyte and abundant functional groups of Ti3C2Tx which can accelerate Li+ migration.

Solid polymer electrolytes (SPEs) have been considered the most promising separators for all-solid-state lithium metal batteries (ASSLMBs) due to their ease of processing and low cost. However, the practical applications of SPEs in ASSLMBs are limited by their low ionic conductivities and mechanical strength. Herein, we developed a three-dimensional (3D) interconnected MXene (Ti3C2Tx) network and Li6.4La3Zr1.4Ta0.6O12 (LLZTO) particles synergistically reinforced polyethylene oxide (PEO)-based SPE, where the association of Li+ with ether-oxygen in PEO could be significantly weakened through the Lewis acid-base interactions between the electron-absorbing group (Ti–F, −O–) of Ti3C2Tx and Li+. Besides, the TFSI− in lithium salts could be immobilized by hydrogen bonds from the Ti–OH of Ti3C2Tx. The 3D interconnected Ti3C2Tx network not only alleviated the agglomeration of inorganic fillers (LLZTO), but also improved the mechanical strength of composite solid electrolyte (CSE). Consequently, the assembled Li||CSE||Li symmetric battery showed excellent cycling stability at 35 ℃ (stable cycling over 3000 h at 0.1 mA cm−2, 0.1 mAh cm−2) and −2 ℃ (stable cycling over 2500 h at 0.05 mA cm−2, 0.05 mAh cm−2). Impressively, the LiFePO4||CSE||Li battery showed a high discharge capacity of 145.3 mAh/g at 0.3 C after 300 cycles at 35 ℃. This rational structural design provided a new strategy for the preparation of high-performance solid-state electrolytes for lithium metal batteries.

ce:data-availability.ce:para: Data will be made available on request.

ce:section.ce:para: Lithium metal batteries (LMBs) have been recognized as the most promising next- generation energy storage devices due to their high energy and power density and market popularity [1]. Unfortunately, conventional lithium metal batteries with liquid organic electrolytes presented serious safety risks such as electrolyte leakage, combustion, and even explosion [2]. All-solid-state batteries (ASSBs) have attracted increasing attention as they can effectively alleviate these safety issues [3–5]. Among the many all-solid organic polymer electrolytes (SPEs), poly(ethylene oxide)(PEO) has significant advantages such as ease of fabrication, low cost, and good stability with lithium metal [6,7]. However, its further practical application has still been seriously hindered by its many shortcomings, such as low ionic conductivity at room temperature (about 10−7 S cm−1) [8], poor interface contact with the electrode material (increased interfacial impedance) [9], bad stability (bad thermal stability and unstable solid electrolyte interphase (SEI)) [10], and low mechanical strength (easy to be pierced by lithium dendrites and result in the phenomenon of short-circuiting) [11,12].

In recent years, many different types of Li-ion conductive fillers have been dispersed in PEO matrices to prepare composite solid electrolytes (CSEs) [13–16], which can not only increase the conductivity of lithium ions, but also improve the mechanical strength of the solid polymer electrolyte. The introduction of inorganic ionic conductors (such as Li6PS5Cl [17], Li7La3Zr2O12 [18], Li0.33La0.56TiO3 [19], Li6.4La3Zr1.4Ta0.6O12 [20], etc.) into PEO-based CSEs could inhibit the crystallization of PEO by disrupting the laminar structure of the surrounding polymer matrix to improve the ionic conductivity of the CSEs [21,22], and the mechanical properties of the CSEs are also improved by their incorporation [15,23]. However, inorganic fillers that tend to agglomerate are difficult to uniformly disperse in viscous PEO solutions, and the performance enhancement of CSEs by fillers is seriously affected [24]. The inorganic fillers in SPEs can be remarkably dispersed uniformly by the incorporation of 3D interconnected nanofiber structures [25,26]. Nevertheless, poor interfacial contacts resulting from their rigid nature limit their further application [27,28], thus the enhancements of ionic conductivity of CSEs by uniformly dispersed inorganic fillers such as LLZTO are not significant, and the prepared all-solid-state batteries are not satisfied for applications at room and low temperatures.

The ionic conductivity can also be improved by virtue of the interaction between Lewis acid sites, electronegative functional groups on the surface of the filler and lithium ions [12,29]. For example, the cyanide group (CN) in Poly (acrylonitrile)(PAN) is a strong electron-absorbing group that can help Li+ conduction [30]. The ionic conductivity of the electrolyte can be enhanced by the interaction of CN with Li+ due to the incorporation of PAN nanofiber membrane [26,31], and the mechanical strength of the electrolyte is significantly enhanced [32]. However, the electrochemical window of CSE with the pure PAN nanofiber membrane can be narrowed due to the poor compatibility between lithium metal and PAN with strong polarity [33,34], and the electrochemical stability of CSE can be improved by the incorporation of other fillers with electron-absorbing group [35].

MXene (Ti3C2Tx) as a new type of 2D carbide material, has been extensively used in energy storage and conversion fields due to its rich surface terminations (Ti–F, −O–, and Ti–OH), high electrical conductivity, excellent lithiophilicity, superior mechanical performance, and strong binding energy with mobile ions [36–43]. On one hand, the association of Li+ with ether-oxygen in PEO can be significantly weakened by the Lewis acid-base interactions between Li+ and the electron-absorbing group (Ti–F, −O–) of Ti3C2Tx, and then Li+ conduction is accelerated in CSEs [44,45]. On the other hand, hydrogen bonds were generated between the Ti–OH of the Ti3C2Tx and PEO polymer base, as obtained in other reports [44,46], which could immobilize the TFSI− in lithium salts to promote the dissociation of lithium salts, thus the ion mobility number is increased by releasing more “Free Li+”. Furthermore, the outstanding flame-resistant performance of MXene was also exhibited [45]. However, the problems of agglomeration and re-stacking would still be present in CSE if MXene was simply compounded with PEO solutions [44,47]. Homogeneous and fast Li+ transport channels cannot be dispersed in fillers and polymers due to random dispersion of fillers [15]. The reinforcing properties of MXene were weakened by the limitations of their effective contact with polymers; thus, their advantages cannot be maximized in CSEs.

Developing a continuous 3D MXene network structure is an effective solution to solve the above problems. The dispersion of additives can be improved by it, and the more “Free Li+” can be produced and the transportation of Li+ can be accelerated in the CSE due to the presence of functional groups on the surface of Ti3C2Tx, as well as the mechanical strength of the solid-state electrolytes can be significantly improved. Therefore, a 3D interconnected MXene nanofiber structure was prepared by electrospinning and then backfilled with polymer, lithium salt and inorganic fillers to obtain a highly stable CSE called PEO/LLZTO/PAN/Ti3C2Tx. The PAN/Ti3C2Tx nanomaterial network with a 3D structure was uniformly mixed in the PEO polymer system, which enables the electrolyte to exhibit high ionic conductivity (2.17 × 10−4 S cm−1, 30 ℃), excellent ionic mobility number (0.74), and wide electrochemical window (∼5.48 V). More importantly, various electrochemical, chemical structural, physical performance characterizations and theoretical calculations are conducted to investigate the conduction mechanism of lithium ions in the CSE. As a result, Li||Li symmetrical cells with PEO/LLZTO/PAN/Ti3C2Tx enable uniform lithium plating/stripping cycling for over 6000 h at 60 ℃ (0.1 mA cm−2, 0.1 mAh cm−2), over 3000 h at 35 ℃ (0.1 mA cm−2, 0.1 mAh cm−2) and over 2500 h at −2 ℃ (0.05 mA cm−2, 0.05 mAh cm−2). Significantly, the assembled LiFePO4||PEO/LLZTO/PAN/Ti3C2Tx||Li full battery achieved high capacity (148.6 mAh g−1 at 60 °C) and high-capacity retention (≈ 89.3 %) after 300 cycles at 2 C. Even at 35 °C, the LiFePO4||Li batteries showed a high discharge capacity of 145.3 mAh g−1 at 0.3 C after 300 cycles. This work provided a new strategy for the preparation of high-performance solid-state electrolytes for lithium metal batteries, indicating its superiority for industrial applications due to its safe, controllable, and environmentally friendly characteristics.

Polyethylene oxide (PEO, Mv = 300,000), lithium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)imide (LiTFSI, 99.5 %), and Polyacrylonitrile (PAN, Mv = 150,000) were purchased from Aladdin chemical reagent (Shanghai) Co., Ltd. Li6.4La3Zr1.4Ta0.6O12 (LLZTO, 5 μm) and carbon black (super P) were offered by Kjmti (Hefei) Co., Ltd. N, N-Dimethylformamide (DMF, ≥ 99.5 %) was purchased from SINOPHARMA Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. Lithium iron phosphate (LFP, 98.0 %) was offered from Macklin chemical reagent (Shanghai) Co., Ltd. Escherichia coli was provided from Beijing Institute of Biological Products Co., Ltd.

The Ti3C2Tx nanosheet powder was dispersed in 5 mL of DMF at a controlled concentration of 10 wt%. Then, the suspension was broken by ultrasonication in a mode of 2 s of operation and 3 s of interval for 30 min (in ice bath), and finally, 0.4 g of PAN was added and stirred for 12 h at room temperature.

The above-prepared spinning solution was filled into a 5 ml syringe and configured with a 21-gauge metal needle. The spinning solution outflow rate was maintained at 1.6 mL/h. The distance between the needle tip and the drum was maintained at 18 cm. The voltage between the needle tip and the drum was set at 16 kV, and the drum was rotated at a speed of 300 rpm. The humidity of the spinning environment was maintained at 40 % and the temperature at 30 °C, respectively. Finally, the PAN/Ti3C2Tx nanofiber membrane was obtained. For comparison, PAN nanofibers were also prepared using the same procedure.

PEO (1.0 g), LiTFSI (0.5 g) (The EO/Li ratio is 13), and LLZTO (0.053 g) were dissolved in 10 mL of anhydrous acetonitrile. After stirring for 24 h to achieve uniformity, the solution was backfilled into a PAN/Ti3C2Tx nanofiber membrane to produce PEO/LLZTO/PAN/Ti3C2Tx electrolyte. The prepared electrolyte films were evaporated in a glove box for 24 h and then dried under vacuum (∼−0.1 MPa) for 24 h at 80 °C. For comparison, the PEO, PEO/LLZTO and PEO/LLZTO/PAN electrolytes were fabricated using the same procedure.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Preparation of LFP electrodes and battery assembly
ce:section.ce:para: PEO (0.15 g) and LiTFSI (0.1 g) were dissolved in 8 mL of anhydrous acetonitrile, then 60 wt% LFP (0.75 g) and carbon black (0.25 g) were added, and the electrode solution was stirred until homogeneous. Scrape the electrode solution onto the aluminum foil to 100 μm. After vacuum drying at 60 °C for 12 h, the electrode sheet was punched into a circular electrode with a diameter of 15 mm. The average effective mass load of the LFP electrode is 1.5 mg/cm2. The CR2032-type ASSLMB was assembled in a glove box with a press of 5 MPa (50 kg/cm2) in an Ar2 atmosphere. The cycle stability and rate performance of the ASSLMB were tested by the LAND measurement system.

The impedance of the solid electrolyte was measured and the ionic conductivity was calculated by electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) in the range of 30 ∼ 70 °C using an electrochemical station (CHI660E, Shanghai, China) in the frequency range of 0.1 Hz ∼ 1.0 M Hz. The cell was assembled by sandwiching the solid electrolyte between two stainless steel electrodes (SS). The ionic conductivities (σ, S cm−1) at different temperatures were calculated from the following equation (1):

The electrochemical stability window of Li/SPE/SS batteries was measured by linear scanning voltammetry (LSV) with a scan rate of 0.1 mV s−1 over the range of open-circuit voltage to 6 V. The cycling performance of LFP full cells was tested by cyclic voltammetry (CV) with a scan rate of 0.1 mV s−1. The cycle stability and multiplicity performance of Li||Li symmetric cells and LFP||Li full cells were tested by constant-current charging and discharging on the LAND measurement system.

Scanning electron microscopy (SEM, Gemini) was used to characterize the morphology of SPEs, nanofiber membranes, and post-cycling lithium electrodes. Elemental analysis of SPE was carried out using an energy spectrometer (EDS, X-max, Oxford Instruments). The 3D morphology and surface roughness of the lithium anode were characterized by the laser scanning confocal microscope (LSCM, Keyence, VK-X200 series). The crystallization behavior of SPE in the range of 10° ∼ 80° was investigated using an x-ray diffractometer (XRD). The Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectra of SPE in the range of 600 ∼ 4000 cm−1 were analyzed using the Thermo Scientific Nicolet iS20 instrument. The JNM-ECZ600R/M1 spectrometer was used for 7Li solid-state NMR experiments. The DSC 200F3 was used for differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) experiments of SPE under N2 atmosphere at −80 ∼ 100 °C with a ramp rate of 10 °C min−1. NETZSCH STA 449F3 was used for thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) of SPE under a N2 atmosphere at 30 ∼ 800 °C with a ramp rate of 10 °C min−1. A CMT6103 mechanical testing machine was used for stress–strain tests of SPE. The Dmol3 module of Material Studio 2020 was used for density-functional theory (DFT) calculations. The interactions between nuclei and electrons were described by the generalized gradient approximation (GGA) method with PBE functions. The force and energy convergence criteria were set to 0.002 Ha Å−1 and 10−5 Ha, respectively.

Fig. 1 a illustrates the Li+ transmission mechanism in different SPEs. In PEO-based SPE, the transmission of Li+ mainly depends on complexation with ether oxygen groups (EO) and movement of the PEO chains [48,49]. In the crystalline region of PEO, Li+ transmission could be hindered by the ordered arrangement of the molecular chains, which results in a low ionic conductivity of PEO SPE [30] (Fig. 1a (i)). For comparison, the addition of LLZTO could decrease the crystallinity of PEO and promote Li+ transport [20,23]. However, the performance enhancement of the CSE by LLZTO could be diminished due to the agglomeration of LLZTO [24] (Fig. 1a (ii)). The LLZTO could be significantly dispersed by the incorporation of PAN nanofiber structures, while the conduction of Li+ could be accelerated by the CN groups in PAN [26,30,31,50] (Fig. 1a (iii)). Furthermore, the association of Li+ with ether-oxygen in PEO could be significantly weakened through Lewis acid-base interactions with Li+ by the electron-absorbing group (Ti–F, −O–) of Ti3C2Tx, and then to accelerate Li+ conduction in CSEs [44,51], a more homogeneous and fast Li+ transport channel was constructed. Besides, hydrogen bonds were generated between the Ti–OH of the Ti3C2Tx and PEO polymer base, which could immobilize the TFSI− in lithium salts to promote the dissociation of lithium salts, thus releasing more “Free Li+” and increasing the ion mobility number to further improve the ionic conductivity of the CSE [45,52] (Fig. 1a (iv)). Fig. 1b shows the Li dendrite growth in different PEO solid-state electrolytes. Due to the low ionic conductivity of PEO electrolyte, the growth of lithium dendrites was produced because of the non-uniform deposition of Li+ on the surface of the Li anode [53] (Fig. 1b (i)). The crystallinity of PEO could be reduced and the mechanical properties of SPE could be enhanced due to the addition of LLZTO, but the enhancement of the electrolyte performance will be attenuated due to the agglomeration of LLZTO (Fig. 1b (ii)). The LLZTO particles could be uniformly dispersed, and the mechanical strength of the CSE could be remarkably improved by the PAN nanofiber membrane, which in turn further reduce the growth of lithium dendrites [25,54] (Fig. 1b (iii)). As PAN/Ti3C2Tx nanofiber membrane is added, the ionic conductivity of CSE could be significantly improved, the formation of stable interface between SPE and Li anode could be promoted, and lithium dendrite growth could be suppressed by PAN/Ti3C2Tx nanofiber (Fig. 1b (iv)).

ce:section.ce:section-title: Characterization of PEO, PEO/LLZTO, PEO/LLZTO/PAN and PEO/LLZTO/PAN/Ti3C2Tx CSEs
ce:section.ce:para: As shown in Fig. S1 and Fig. 2 a, the pure PAN nanofibers were white and had a smooth surface. While with the addition of Ti3C2Tx, the uniform grayish color indicated uniform dispersion of Ti3C2Tx on the nanofibers. Meanwhile, the surface of the nanofibers became rough and the diameter of the fibers increased with typical wrinkles (Fig. 2b). From the relative positions of Ti3C2Tx and PAN, the Ti3C2Tx nanosheets were dispersed in PAN in a longitudinally stretched or wrapped manner without significant agglomeration. The folds on the fibers are sharp edges exposed by the Ti3C2Tx nanosheets, which implies that the reactive zones are increased by electrospinning, thus favoring interactions with ions as well as antimicrobial activity [55]. Elemental mapping shows that O, F, and Ti are uniformly distributed on the nanofibers (Fig. 2c and Fig. S2), thus indicating the successful coupling of Ti3C2Tx nanosheets with PAN nanofibers. The top-view SEM image and EDS element mappings (Fig. 2d, e, and Fig. S3) demonstrate the dense surface and uniform element distribution of PEO/LLZTO/PAN/Ti3C2Tx CSE. The cross-sectional view of the SEM image (Fig. 2f) showed that the thickness of PEO/LLZTO/PAN/Ti3C2Tx CSE was 190 μm. Moreover, complete cross–sections and EDS element mappings (Fig. 2g and Fig. S4) also confirmed that the PAN/Ti3C2Tx network was fully infiltrated with PEO electrolyte. The obtained PEO/LLZTO/PAN/Ti3C2Tx CSE performed with excellent mechanical properties, which were attested by various mechanical deformations such as bending, twisting, and rolling (Fig. S5). The dispersing effect of the nanofiber structure on the LLZTO particles in the electrolyte can be explained by the corresponding SEM images and elemental analysis. As can be seen from the SEM images (Fig. S6), there is agglomeration of LLZTO particles in PEO/LLZTO CSE. In contrast, the LLZTO particles in the PEO/LLZTO/PAN/Ti3C2Tx CSE were uniformly distributed. In addition, elemental mapping showed that LLZTO corresponding to La, Zr, and Ta elements were uniformly distributed in PEO/LLZTO/PAN/Ti3C2Tx CSE. The results indicate that the nanofiber structure is beneficial in inhibiting the agglomeration of LLZTO particles. The uniformly dispersed LLZTO particles not only reduced the degree of polymer crystallization, but also formed a new additional pathway for Li+ conduction in the electrolyte by the oxide layer on its surface [56].

The properties of CSE were affected by the crystallinity of PEO. X-ray diffraction (XRD) spectra (Fig. 2h) showed that PEO/LLZTO/PAN/Ti3C2Tx CSE had the lowest peak intensities and the widest half-peak widths corresponding to the PEO semicrystalline structure at 19° and 23° (FWHM, Table S1), indicating there are more amorphous regions that is conducive to Li+ migration [57,58]. Fig. 2i and Fig. S7 showed the IR spectra of the four electrolytes and the clay-like Ti3C2Tx, in which the presence of Ti–F and Ti–O bonds were found at 887.6 cm−1 and 694.3 cm−1 for PEO/LLZTO/PAN/Ti3C2Tx, and the CN stretching vibration was found at 2198.9 cm−1 for PEO/LLZTO/PAN/Ti3C2Tx and PEO/LLZTO/PAN, which proves the successful preparation of the PAN/Ti3C2Tx structure [26,45]. The three peaks at 1186.9, 1095.8, and 1055.8 cm−1 of the PEO solid-state electrolyte spectrum correspond sequentially to the C–H, C–O–C, and C–O of the PEO [59–61]. However, the wave numbers of three similar peaks in the PEO/LLZTO/PAN/Ti3C2Tx spectra undergo a slight redshift to 1189.4, 1097.8, and 1058.7 cm−1, respectively, suggesting the formation of O–Li electron pairs between the EO chains and more Li+, which reduces the vibrational energy levels of the corresponding bonds. In addition, the position 1350.3 cm−1 in the spectrum of PEO corresponds to the O–H in PEO/LLZTO/PAN/Ti3C2Tx, which is also red-shifted (1352.4 cm−1), proving that there is a hydrogen bond between the capped functional group of Ti3C2Tx and the polymer molecule [44,46]. In order to further verify that the presence of functional groups on the surface of Ti3C2Tx and the PAN/Ti3C2Tx nanofiber membrane also possess excellent antimicrobial properties, we did antimicrobial experiments on E. coli. The inactivation process of Ti3C2Tx against E. coli is shown in Fig. S8a. On the one hand, the sharp edges of Ti3C2Tx nanosheets can disrupt the plasma membrane and cell wall of E. coli, resulting in cytoplasmic leakage and the release of bacterial DNA from the cytosol, which leads to cell lysis and the death of E. coli cells [62] (Fig. S8a (i)); on the other hand, the anionic nature of Ti3C2Tx enhances the bacteria inactivation via direct contact-killing mechanism due to the existence of strong electron absorbing groups (−F, etc.), and H-bonding between oxygenate groups of MXene (−O–, –OH) with lipopolysaccharide cords on the bacteria membrane disrupts the nutrient intake by the bacteria [63–65] (Fig. S8a (ii)). As shown in Fig. S8b, with the increase in the mixing time between the E. coli bacterial solution and the PAN/Ti3C2Tx nanofiber membrane, the number of E. coli colonies in the culture medium decreased significantly. Fig. S8c shows a more obvious limitation of E. coli propagation in comparison with the blank control group in parallel time, indicating the obvious antibacterial activity of the PAN/Ti3C2Tx nanofiber membrane. According to the simulated k value of 0.00595 min−1 in Fig. S8d, it indicates the high inactivation efficiency of PAN/Ti3C2Tx nanofiber membrane against E. coli by destroying the plasma membrane and cell wall of E. coli and impeding the intake of nutrients through the sharp edges of Ti3C2Tx nanosheets [55] and abundant surface groups [63–65]. As shown in Fig. S8e, the bacterial inactivation efficiency of the E. coli bacterial solution mixed with PAN/Ti3C2Tx nanofiber membrane for 6.5 h reached 97 %, which proved the sterilization effect of the PAN/Ti3C2Tx nanofiber membrane. The antimicrobial effectiveness of PAN/Ti3C2Tx nanofiber membrane was also confirmed by the antibacterial activity determination of E. coli, which in turn confirmed the successful fabrication of Ti3C2Tx nanosheets and the existence of the functional groups.

Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was used to examine the thermal stability of CSE (Fig. 2j), and a slight weight loss was found before 200 °C, which was due to the evaporation of water absorbed by CSE exposed to air [66]. Subsequently, due to the decomposition of the PEO and PAN nanofiber membranes, the weight of the CSE decreases dramatically in the temperature range of 320 ∼ 450 °C. The remaining weight of the PEO/LLZTO/PAN/Ti3C2Tx electrolyte after decomposition is 13.69 wt%. It can be seen that the electrolyte containing PAN/Ti3C2Tx nanofiber film shows a thermal degradation temperature similar to that of the PEO electrolytic liquid, which indicates that the addition of PAN/Ti3C2Tx nanofiber film helps the composite electrolyte maintain a high thermal stability, thereby improving the safety of the battery [67]. From the 7Li solid-state nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectrum, it can be seen that the chemical shift of the PEO/LLZTO/PAN/Ti3C2Tx electrolyte drifted towards the lower field by about 0.12 ppm with respect to the PEO electrolyte (Fig. 2k), which suggests a weakening of the PEO-Li+ interaction [68,69].This suggests that the incorporation of PAN/Ti3C2Tx can attenuate the adsorption of lithium ions by EO, thus promoting the migration of lithium ions. The results of the DSC curves (Fig. 2l) further indicate that the presence of PAN/Ti3C2Tx nanofiber films reduces the crystallinity of PEO. It can be seen that the PEO/LLZTO/PAN/Ti3C2Tx electrolyte has a low glass transition temperature (−48 °C). The low Tg favors the movement of PEO chain segments in the electrolyte, which is beneficial to Li+ transport [67,70]. Meanwhile, the PEO/LLZTO/PAN/Ti3C2Tx electrolyte has the lowest Tm of 29 °C, which ensures that the solid-state battery has a low operating temperature. The practical application of CSE in batteries could be guaranteed by its excellent mechanical properties. The stress–strain curves of PEO, PEO/LLZTO, PEO/LLZTO/PAN, and PEO/LLZTO/PAN/Ti3C2Tx are shown in Fig. 2m. With the addition of LLZTO, the tensile strength of CSE increased from 0.18 MPa (PEO) to 0.23 MPa (PEO/LLZTO), indicating that the addition of inorganic fillers can enhance the mechanical strength of SPE [23]. The tensile strength of PEO/LLZTO/PAN CSE was increased to 2.37 MPa after the addition of PAN nanofiber membranes, indicating that electrostatically spun nanofiber membranes can substantially improve the mechanical strength of CSE [31,32]. Then, due to the mechanical strength of Ti3C2Tx nanosheets itself, the Ti3C2Tx-reinforced PEO/LLZTO/PAN/Ti3C2Tx three-dimensional fiber network can further increase the tensile strength of CSE to 2.91 MPa [37]. Excellent mechanical properties allow the electrolyte to inhibit the growth of lithium dendrites, which in turn allows the battery to cycle stably [71]. Besides, optical images of PEO and PEO/LLZTO/PAN/Ti3C2Tx CSEs under a combustion test are shown in Fig. S9. The PEO/LLZTO/PAN/Ti3C2Tx CSE could not be quickly ignited in the flame, even for 10 s. It indicated that the safety of the battery was improved by the good flame-retardant properties of PEO/LLZTO/PAN/Ti3C2Tx CSE [24].

ce:section.ce:section-title: Electrochemical stability of PEO, PEO/LLZTO, PEO/LLZTO/PAN and PEO/LLZTO/PAN/ Ti3C2Tx CSEs
ce:section.ce:para: As a result, high ionic conductivity is endowed with PEO/LLZTO/PAN/Ti3C2Tx (2.17 × 10−4 S cm−1) at 30 ℃. The highest ionic conductivity and the lowest impedance of PEO/LLZTO/PAN/Ti3C2Tx than PEO, PEO/LLZTO, and PEO/LLZTO/PAN from 30 ∼ 70 ℃ is shown by Fig. 3 a and S10. These results can be attributed to three aspects. Firstly, a large interaction exists between the LLZTO nanostructured fillers with a large specific surface area and polymers, which can restrain the recrystallization of polymer chains and thereby improve the ionic conductivity of composite electrolytes [48]. Secondly, the CN in the PAN nanofiber membrane can weaken the adsorption of Li+ by ether-oxygen bonds thereby facilitating the migration of Li+ [30,72]. Finally, the addition of Ti3C2Tx can significantly improve the ionic conductivity of CSE through the rich functional groups (−F, –OH, and −O–) on the surface of Ti3C2Tx to restrict TFSI− and accelerate the migration of Li+ [44,45,51]. In addition, the activation energy (Ea) is an important parameter to describe the transport behavior of lithium ions in the electrolyte [73]. As shown in Fig. 3b, the Ea (0.32 eV) of PEO/LLZTO/PAN/Ti3C2Tx is the lowest by the calculation of the Arrhenius equation. The low Ea indicates that Li+ has a weaker affinity for EO, and the energy barrier for Li+ transport is lower, which in turn allows faster migration between polymer chain segments [74]. In addition, the electrochemical stability window (ESW) of these CSEs was also explored. LSV curves showed that PEO, PEO/LLZTO, and PEO/LLZTO/PAN electrolytes started to decompose at 4.91 V, 5.09 V, and 5.17 V, respectively, while PEO/LLZTO/PAN/Ti3C2Tx decomposed at 5.48 V (Fig. 3c). The large electrochemical stabilization window suggests that CSE can be applied to high-pressure ASSLMBs [75]. Similarly, the tLi + of PEO/LLZTO/PAN/Ti3C2Tx (Fig. 3e) is much higher (0.74) at 60 ℃ than that of PEO (0.35) (Fig. 3d), PEO/LLZTO (0.43) (Fig. S11a), and PEO/LLZTO/PAN (0.58) (Fig. S11b), reflecting more “Free Li+” being released due to the immobilization of the TFSI− in lithium salts by hydrogen bonds.

In addition, the characterization of the electrochemical reactions in the solid-state battery was evaluated by CV (Fig. 3f). The lower REDOX peak voltage difference and more significant current flow of LFP||PEO/LLZTO/PAN/Ti3C2Tx||Li, compared to the other three full cells battery, reflects its fast electrochemical kinetics and high electrochemical reversibility [67,74]. After the first cycles’ activation process, the CV curves of the LFP||PEO/LLZTO/PAN/Ti3C2Tx||Li (Fig. S12b) are highly overlapping, and no other reaction peaks appeared, suggesting better reversibility and electrochemical stability of the cell compared to LFP||PEO||Li (Fig. S12a) [76]. The density functional theory (DFT) was conducted to further investigate the interaction between Li+ and Ti3C2Tx as well as PEO. Fig. 3g, h reveals that the binding energy of PEO-Li+ is calculated to be −4.35 eV. In contrast, the binding energy of PEO@Ti3C2Tx-Li+ (−3.87 eV) is significantly weaker. Proving that the association of Li+ with −O- through Lewis acid-base interactions with Li+ was significantly weakened by the electron-absorbing group (Ti–F, −O–) of Ti3C2Tx. This is highly consistent with the experimental results.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Symmetric battery performance of PEO, PEO/LLZTO, PEO/LLZTO/PAN and PEO/LLZTO/PAN/Ti3C2Tx CSEs
ce:section.ce:para: Excellent electrochemical stability and high ionic conductivity are necessary conditions for solid-state batteries in practical applications [77]. The interfacial stability of the electrolyte is investigated by assembling Li||SPE||Li symmetric cells. The EIS profiles of Li||PEO||Li, Li||PEO/LLZTO||Li, Li||PEO/LLZTO/PAN||Li, and Li||PEO/LLZTO/PAN/Ti3C2Tx||Li before cycling is shown in Fig. 4 a. It can be found that the impedance of Li||PEO/LLZTO/PAN/Ti3C2Tx||Li before cycling is the lowest, demonstrating that the close interface was formed due to functional groups in the PAN/Ti3C2Tx nanofiber membrane facilitating lithium ion conduction [78], which in turn reduces the interfacial impedance.

The long constant-current charge/discharge process can further quantify the cycling stability of the battery. As shown in Fig. 4b, Li||PEO/LLZTO/PAN/Ti3C2Tx||Li can maintain stable lithium plating/stripping over 6000, 4000, and 2500 h at 0.1 mA cm−2 and 0.1 mAh cm−2, 0.2 mA cm−2 and 0. 2 mAh cm−2, 0.3 mA cm−2 and 0.3 mAh cm−2 respectively, and has a low overpotential at 60 °C, which is attributed to the excellent mechanical strength and high ionic conductivity of PEO/LLZTO/PAN/Ti3C2Tx. The results show that lithium ions can be transported rapidly and can be deposited uniformly on the electrode surface. This leads to the formation of a stable interfacial layer, thus suppressing the growth of lithium dendrites and ensuring cycling stability [45,79]. The high ionic conductivity of CSEs at room temperature and low temperature is a prerequisite for SSLMBs to be widely used. Therefore, we tested the long cycling performance of Li||PEO||Li, Li||PEO/LLZTO||Li, Li||PEO/LLZTO/PAN||Li, and Li||PEO/LLZTO/PAN/Ti3C2Tx||Li at 35 °C and −2 °C, respectively. The results show that Li||PEO/LLZTO/PAN/Ti3C2Tx||Li can stably cycle at a lower overpotential at 0.1 mA cm−2 and 0.1 mAh cm−2 for more than 3000 h at 35 °C, and stably cycle at 0.05 mA cm−2 and 0.05 mAh cm−2 for more than 2500 h at −2 °C, which is much better than the other three SPEs, which suggests the good properties of PEO/LLZTO/PAN/Ti3C2Tx at room and low temperatures as well. The stable cycling performance of symmetric cells is attributed to the multiple ion mobility numbers, fast ion transport, and good mechanical properties of PEO/LLZTO/PAN/Ti3C2Tx, which are able to inhibit the growth of lithium dendrites and ensure stable and uniform plating/stripping of lithium over time [80–82].

To highlight the effect of the PAN/Ti3C2Tx nanofiber membrane on improving the electrochemical performance of symmetric batteries, Li||PEO||Li, Li||PEO/LLZTO||Li, Li||PEO/LLZTO/PAN||Li, and Li||PEO/LLZTO/PAN/Ti3C2Tx||Li batteries underwent lithium plating/stripping (Fig. 4c) at different current densities at 60 ℃. The results show the lowest overpotential at all current densities of Li||PEO/LLZTO/PAN/Ti3C2Tx||Li, which proves that more lithium ions are released and lithium ions gain faster conduction through the functional groups, which in turn helps to maintain a lower interfacial resistance and stabilize the interfacial layer [59]. As shown in Fig. 4d, the critical current density (CCD) was tested to further check the durability of CSE during charging and discharging. It can be seen that Li||PEO||Li shows voltage fluctuation and short circuit at 0.7 mA cm−2, while the critical current density of Li||PEO/LLZTO/PAN/Ti3C2Tx||Li could reach 2 mA cm−2 after the addition of both LLZTO and PAN/Ti3C2Tx nanofiber film, indicating the good mechanical strength and high ionic conductivity of PEO/LLZTO/PAN/Ti3C2Tx [12].

Furthermore, Fig. 5 a, b, c, d, and S13a show the SEM images of the surface of the Li anode in different Li symmetric batteries after 200 h of Li plating/stripping and before polarization. It can be seen that the post-cycling lithium anode surface of Li||PEO||Li is rough, which is due to the low ionic conductivity and poor mechanical properties of the electrolyte, resulting in irregular lithium dendrites on the electrode surface. In contrast, the lithium anode surfaces of Li||PEO/LLZTO||Li and Li||PEO/LLZTO/PAN||Li symmetric cells are relatively flat with fewer defects, indicating the fast ionic conductivity and good mechanical properties of the SPEs after the addition of LLZTO and PAN nanofiber membranes [82], which are conducive to the uniform deposition of Li+. Fig. 5d shows a smoother and denser lithium anode surface in Li||PEO/LLZTO/PAN/Ti3C2Tx||Li, confirming that lithium is more uniformly deposited on the lithium metal anode, and that PEO/LLZTO/PAN/Ti3C2Tx effectively inhibits the formation of lithium tree dendrites due to its fast ionic transport and good interfacial stability. Meanwhile, in order to better characterize the roughness of the surface of the Li anode after cycling, we did laser confocal tests on the Li anode after cycling for 200 h in different Li symmetric batteries, and Fig. 5e, f, g, h, and S13b show the 2D and 3D morphology of the surface of the different Li anodes, respectively, and it can be seen that the surface roughness of the Li anode in PEO/LLZTO/PAN/Ti3C2Tx after cycling for 200 h is the lowest (Sa = 1.265 μm), which proves that PEO/LLZTO/PAN/Ti3C2Tx can lead to uniform deposition of Li+ on the surface of lithium metal anode and has the ability to inhibit the growth of lithium dendrites due to the high ionic conductivity and excellent mechanical strength [83].

ce:section.ce:section-title: Full battery performance of PEO, PEO/LLZTO, PEO/LLZTO/PAN and PEO/LLZTO/PAN/Ti3C2Tx CSEs
ce:section.ce:para: We assembled PEO, PEO/LLZTO, PEO/LLZTO/PAN, and PEO/LLZTO/PAN/Ti3C2Tx electrolytes into LFP all-solid-state batteries to evaluate the electrochemical performances and further validate the feasibility of SPEs for practical applications. A schematic diagram of the solid-state Li metal battery structure is shown in Fig. S14. LFP||PEO/LLZTO/PAN/Ti3C2Tx||Li exhibits excellent multiplicative performance (Fig. 6 a), with discharge specific capacities of 167.3, 156.1, 147.6, 140.3, 133.7, and 128.4 mAh g−1 at 0.5 C, 1 C, 2 C, 3 C, 4 C, and 5 C, and coulombic efficiency close to 100 % even at 4 C and 5 C, showing good multiplicative performance. This may be attributed to the fast ionic conductivity that allows more uniform Li+ deposition at the electrolyte–electrode interface, which effectively improves the electrochemical stability [84]. The corresponding charge–discharge curves are shown in Fig. S15, and the LFP||PEO/LLZTO/PAN/Ti3C2Tx||Li battery exhibits the more stable voltage plateau at all current densities.

LiFePO4||Li cells with different solid-state electrolytes were cycled at 0.5 C (Fig. 6b) and 1C (Fig. 6c) for a long period of time at 60 °C, respectively, and they showed an average coulombic efficiency (CE) of about 100 %, which confirms the wide applicability of PEO-based solid-state electrolytes. However, after a comprehensive comparison of capacity and stability, LFP||PEO/LLZTO/PAN/Ti3C2Tx||Li with the addition of PAN/Ti3C2Tx nanofiber membranes stood out. Specifically, LFP||PEO/LLZTO/PAN/Ti3C2Tx||Li has a high initial discharge specific capacity of 166.4 mAhg−1 and a retained discharge capacity of 160.2 mAhg−1 at 0.5 C with a capacity retention rate of 96.3 %; and a high initial discharge specific capacity of 155.1 mAhg−1 and a retained discharge capacity of 139.1 mAhg−1 at 1 C with a capacity retention rate of 89.7 %, both at 60 °C with stable cycling over 300 turns and an average CE of over 99.9 %, reflecting the good interfacial stability of the electrolyte and electrode and the fast Li+ transport kinetics [74,85], corresponding to low ohmic polarization and activation polarization. In contrast, the capacity of the LFP||PEO/LLZTO||Li and LFP||PEO/LLZTO/PAN||Li decreased significantly after 300 cycles. Even the discharge specific capacity of LFP/PEO/Li gradually tends to zero at less than 300 cycles, it is shown that the PEO electrolyte is penetrated and short-circuited by lithium dendrites due to its low ionic conductivity and poor mechanical properties. In addition, LFP||PEO/LLZTO/PAN/Ti3C2Tx||Li maintained a low overpotential at different multiplicities (Figs. S16 and 17), demonstrating better interfacial compatibility and faster reaction kinetics.

Fig. 6d shows the discharge performance and coulombic efficiency of LiFePO4 full batteries with different electrolyte combinations at high rates (2 C) at 60 °C. As shown, the introduction of LLZTO and PAN/Ti3C2Tx nanofiber membranes into the PEO matrix reduces the capacity degradation of the LFP full cell. In particular, the discharge specific capacity retention of LFP||PEO/LLZTO/PAN/Ti3C2Tx||Li is 90.2 % after 300 cycles, and the coulombic efficiency is close to 100 %. The corresponding specific capacitance voltage profile also exhibits a typical charge/discharge profile of 2.6 ∼ 4.2 V (Fig. 6e and S18). In contrast, the Coulombic efficiency and discharge specific capacity of LFP||PEO||Li decreased dramatically after 140 cycles, which may be related to the low ionic conductivity and Li dendrite growth. In addition, the cycling performance of solid-state batteries at room temperature is important. The long-cycle performance of full batteries assembled with different electrolytes was tested at 35 °C, 0.3 C, and it can be seen that the most stable performance of LFP||PEO/LLZTO/PAN/Ti3C2Tx||Li (Fig. 6f), with capacity retention as high as 100 after 300 cycles, indicates the high ionic conductivity and fast lithium-ion migration of PEO/LLZTO/PAN/Ti3C2Tx even at room temperature. The excellent performance of the PEO/LLZTO/PAN/Ti3C2Tx electrolyte is also confirmed by the charge–discharge curves in Fig. 6g and S19, which show that there is a small band gap between the charge–discharge platforms, highlighting the high ionic conductivity and the small interfacial impedance. The current time specifications and the active substance loadings of the LFP||PEO/LLZTO/PAN/Ti3C2Tx||Li after applying the voltage are shown in Fig. S20.

In summary, a high-performance PEO-based solid electrolyte with the synergistic effect of PAN/Ti3C2Tx nanofiber and LLZTO particles was prepared. The Li+ conductivity, electrochemical stability, and mechanical properties of CSE could be improved by the 3D interconnected Ti3C2Tx network through its surface-rich functional groups and uniformly dispersed particle behavior of LLZTO particles. Meanwhile, the flame resistance of the electrolyte was improved by the instinctive stability of Ti3C2Tx. Therefore, the resulting PEO/LLZTO/PAN/Ti3C2Tx CSE exhibited high ionic conductivity (2.17 × 10−4 Scm−1, 30 ℃), a high Li+ transference number (0.74), and a wide potential window (5.48 V). As a consequence, the Li||Li symmetric batteries assembled with the PEO/LLZTO/PAN/Ti3C2Tx CSE exhibited long-term cycling stability over 3000 h at 35 ℃ with a low overpotential and excellent reversibility in long-term lithium plating/stripping tests. As a proof of concept, the ASSLMBs combined with LiFePO4 cathode exhibited impressively improved rate capability and cycling stability, showing high-capacity retention of 90.1 % after 300 cycles at 0.3 C at 35 ℃. This rational structural design provides a new strategy for the preparation of high-performance solid-state electrolytes for lithium metal batteries.
